question: null
solution:
"
Motorola is aware of a potential customer experience issue on the Moto E6i product related to Battery and Power On/Off issues. Some users reported experiencing issues where their Moto E6i device would rapidly drain the Battery and/or Power Off automatically.

Engineering analysis determined two potential causes for the issues experienced by Moto E6i users.
  1. Battery Meter Calibration - In some cases the Battery Meter Calibration value can be lost resulting in rapid Battery Drain and invalid Low Battery Shutdown events.
     
  2. Sleepmode Recovery - In some rare cases where the device is left in an idle state with the display off, a timing issue may occur preventing the Memory IC from properly waking up from sleepmode. This leaves the device in an unresponsive black screen state which appears to the user as Powered Off. Typically, a long-press of the Pwr-Key is required to recover from this state
Solution

Motorola has identified and implemented fixes for the two potential causes above into the latest versions of phone software, QOH30.251-15 and later. The new software will be made available to users via OTA Update starting in April 2021.
Call Center Action

When responding to Moto E6i users reporting issues where their Moto E6i device would rapidly drain the Battery and/or itself Power Off, then:
Determine if new phone software, QOH30.251-15 and later, is available for their Moto E6i device.
  1. If a new phone software is available, then first complete the Short-Term Work-Around steps to force a re-calibration of the Battery Meter and secondly assist the user with updating their device to the latest approved SW Release (QOH30.251-15 and later), via OTA Update or Lenovo Moto Smart Assistant (LMSA) Tool, to resolve the user's issue.
     
  2. If new phone software is not yet available, then assist the user with completing the Short-Term Work-Around steps below to force a re-calibration of the Battery Meter. Inform the user that a new software will be made available via OTA Update soon to further resolve the issue.
Short-Term Work-Around: Prior to the availability of new phone software, QOH30.251-15 and later, affected users can force a re-calibration of the Battery Meter by completing steps below:
  1. Press and Hold the Power Button for 10 seconds until the device resets.
     
  2. Connect the device to a charger and allow the device to charge completely to 100% (user should leave the device on the charger for at least 1 hour after reaching the 100%), this will calibrate the battery meter allowing it to function properly.
NOTE: Prior to QOH30.251-15 and later phone software, the device may still have the possibility of re-entering the bad meter calibration condition.
"
summary: BULLETIN_Moto E6i - Quick Battery Drain and Device Power Off

question: null
"Problems sending or receiving messages "
solution:
"

If you are having problems sending or receiving messages on your device, it may be because your SIM card has not been provisioned correctly by Verizon. 

 

To correct the problem:

 

If you are using your existing SIM card, please log-in to Verizon’s website and visit Account > My Devices > Activate or switch device > Activate on an existing line to enable CDMA-less on your SIM. 

If the steps above did not correct the issue:

 

1 - Call Verizon at 1-800-922-0204 or visit a local Verizon store

2 - Inform them you have a new phone with an existing SIM card and messaging is not working

3 - Let them know you need to add CDMA-less provisioning to your account.

 

Note: In most cases you should begin receiving recently sent messages immediately. In certain cases, it may take a few hours for provisioning to be completed. 

Tips:

Ensure you are using Message+ version V.7.0.7 and later.

If you are switching from an Apple phone and can't get SMS or text messages someone sends you from an iPhone, you may need to turn off iMessage. Visit https://selfsolve.apple.com/deregister-imessage/ for steps to deregister iMessage from your iPhone or from a computer.

"

solution:

question:
"
Why are my Android apps crashing?
\n"
categories(Name): Issue|Notifications|Important Issues / Hot Topics|Missing Preloaded App|Google Apps (music, Movies, Books...)|Google Photos App
solution:
"
Google recently released an update to the Android System Webview that resulted in several apps having issues, such as force close, or unable to open.
 
Google has corrected the issue with updates to both Android System Webview and Chrome.
 
If you are having issues with apps crashing ensure you update Android System WebView to version 89.0.4389.105 and Google Chrome to the latest version.
"

question: null

"

What's new in Android 11 ?

\n"
solution:
"
After upgrading, you'll see the following improvements to the Android operating system and other apps.
 
Notification improvements

Conversations
When you view notifications, you'll see a new Conversations section, just for message apps:
  • You’ll see notification counts in the preview if you have multiple notifications in the same conversation.
  • You can mark conversations as Priority to keep them on top of the list and using a bubble. The contact’s photo will show on the lock screen and in your notifications.
Bubbles
Bubbles keep your conversations accessible by floating over any app you’re using:
  • Drag the bubble to move it around the screen.
  • Read and send messages from the bubble without opening the app.
  • You can turn bubbles off from any conversation notification.
One-time permissions
Keep closer control of your most sensitive permissions, like camera and mic access, by granting an app permission for one-time use only. The next time the app wants to access the feature, you’ll be asked to again grant permission.
 
Auto-reset permissions
If you haven’t used an app for an extended period of time, your phone will auto-reset all permissions associated with that app and will notify you.
  • You can re-grant the app permissions the next time you open the app.
  • The option to grant permission all the time is no longer available for many apps.
  • If an app requests permission multiple times and you repeatedly deny it, the app will be blocked from requesting the permission again.
Other improvements
  • Notification history now lets you access notifications you accidentally swiped away.
  • You can now hide Silent notifications from the unexpanded status bar view, and see them only when it’s expanded.
Navigation

Quick settings and media controls
Media controls are now in quick settings, instead of in your notifications, for easier access:
  • From media controls, you can now switch between the phone’s speaker and other connected devices.
  • You can now swipe away the media controls if you don’t want to see them when you've stopped listening to music.
New features in Power menu
When you press & hold the Power button, you'll see the Power menu. This menu now includes:
  • Toggles, sliders, live video streaming, and a temperature control panel to control your connected smart home devices.
  • Quick access to Google Wallet.
  • The Screenshot option has moved from this menu to Recent apps, for easier access.
Changes to Recent apps
  • You can now take screenshots from your list of recent apps.
  • Suggested apps no longer appear in your recent apps. They're at the bottom of your home screen.
System improvements

Custom dark mode scheduling
  • You can now schedule Dark theme to turn on based on custom times or the sunset.
  • If you turned on Dark theme in Settings, you can turn it off within individual apps that support light/dark modes.
Screen recorder
Capture a video of your screen while you're using it:
  • Start recording conveniently from quick settings or when you're playing a game.
  • Use the selfie camera to capture audio or video of yourself narrating while you record.
Nearby Share
Nearby Share improves the sharing ecosystem. Now you can share files and links easily and securely with Android phones near yours, without revealing contact information:
  • No internet connection required.
  • Turn sharing on or off in quick settings.
Do Not Disturb mode
When you're adjusting these settings:
  • You can allow selected people to call or, separately, text you.
  • You can allow selected apps to send notifications when Do Not Disturb is on.
When Do Not Disturb is on, both audio and vibration will be muted for system-generated sounds like alarms or reminders.
Other system improvements
  • Now any smartphone with Android 11 and 5GHz Wi-Fi can use Android Auto wirelessly.
  • You can now customize back gesture sensitivity on both sides of the screen, making it easier to tap menus and use gestures.
  • When you turn on airplane mode, Bluetooth now stays connected and Bluetooth headphones won’t disconnect.
  • You can get app suggestions and pin suggested apps at the bottom of your home screen.
  • Accessibility features now have a shortcut to start them from the lock screen.
"

question:
"

How can I change the default USB setting on my Motorola phone?

\n"
solution:
"
When you connect your Motorola phone and computer with the USB cable, the phone’s USB connection type is set to charging mode, which charges your battery but prevents your computer from seeing files on your phone.
 
To change the USB connection type to allow file transfers, swipe down from the top of your home screen and touch the Charging this device via USB notification.
If you regularly transfer files, you can choose to change the default USB connection setting, by following the steps below:
 
1 - Enable Developer Options
  1. Go to Settings > System
     
  2. Touch About phone
     
  3. Touch the Build number field 7 times



    You will begin seeing a message as you approach the 7 touches
     
  4. Touch the back arrow once complete, and developer options will now appear under Settings > System > Advanced > Developer options. 
2 - Change Default Setting
  1. Go to Settings
     
  2. Type USB in the search bar

     
  3. Scroll down and select Default USB configuration

     
  4. Select Default USB configuration
  5. Make your desired selection
  6. Touch the back arrow once complete
"

solution:
"

Take a selfie

Use beauty filter
 
Your front (selfie) camera includes a beautification filter. Use it to:
  • Soften and even skin tone
  • Remove blemishes and shine
  • Whiten teeth
  • Highlight T-zone
  • Slenderize face
  • Enlarge and brighten eyes
To use the filter:

  2. Touch  and then:
     
    • Touch  to use automatic mode.
       
    • Touch  to use manual mode, then adjust the intensity of the filter with the slider.
       
  3. Smile and touch  to take the picture.
To turn the filter off, touch  or  and change to

Use mirroring

For the front (selfie) camera, when you look in the viewfinder, you'll see a mirror image: left and right are reversed, and text looks backwards. You can control, however, whether the photos you take match the viewfinder or whether they're flipped.
  1. On the viewfinder, touch  Settings
     
  2. For Selfie photo mirror:
    • If you want photos to match what you see in the viewfinder, turn it on
    • If you want text in photos to read normally and the image to be flipped, turn it off

question:
"

How can I take moving cinemagraphs on the motorola one ?

\n"
solution:
"

Cinemagraphs allow you to animate part of your photo while the rest remains still.

To create an image with a splash of motion:

  1. On the viewfinder, touch   > Cinemagraph

  2. Hold the phone steady.

  3. Touch & hold  to capture the scene.

  4. The camera suggests a portion of the scene to keep in motion or freeze. To change these settings:

    • Touch , then swipe over the part to keep in motion.

    • Touch  , then swipe over the part to freeze.

  5. To edit the frames used, adjust the sliders.

  6. To change the style of loop, touch the style shown:

    • Regular loop repeats the loop from start to end.

    • Bounce loop repeats the loop from start to end, then reverses the action.

  7. Touch PREVIEW to view the cinemagraph, then do one of the following:

    • Choose whether to save it as GIF or MP4, then touch SAVE

    • To reverse your changes, touch CLEAR

    • To discard without saving, touch

"

question: "How can I share the motorola one internet connection?"
solution:
"
Want to use the internet on a laptop computer or tablet but don't have a connection? You can share your phone's cellular data connection with multiple devices by turning your phone into a Wi‑Fi hotspot. 
 
Note: Your cellular plan must support data sharing. If you don’t know, contact your carrier.

Set up Wi‑Fi hotspot
  1. Check that cellular data is on. If cellular data is off, your phone doesn't have an internet connection to share.
  2. Go to Settings > Network & internet > Mobile Hotspot & tethering
  3. Touch Mobile Hotspot and do any:
    • To make it easier to identify your hotspot when connecting to it, change the network name for your hotspot.
    • To prevent others from seeing your phone's network name, check Hide my device
    • To see the current password, touch Advanced > Hotspot password
    • If the hotspot signal is experiencing interference, touch Advanced and change the AP Band (broadcast channel) to 5GHz.
Connect devices to hotspot
  1. Check that cellular data is on. If cellular data is off, your phone doesn't have an internet connection to share.
  2. Go to Settings > Network & internet > Mobile Hotspot & tethering
  3. Touch Wi-Fi hotspot and turn it on

    When your hotspot is active, you'll see  in the status bar.
    Tip: The first time you turn the hotspot on,  is added to quick settings. After that, just swipe the status bar down and touch  to turn the hotspot off/on.
  4. Set up the connection
To connect Do this
A phone On your phone, next to the hotspot's name, touch  and unlock if prompted.

Use the other phone's camera to scan the QR code that provides the password.
Other device  Open the device’s Wi-Fi settings.

Select your phone’s hotspot.

Enter the hotspot password. Learn how to find the hotspot's password.
    
To disconnect devices from your hotspot, touch Wi-Fi hotspot and turn it off. When you turn it back on, devices with the password can connect automatically. To prevent this, change the password.
Manage hostpot connections

Tip: When no devices are connected, the hotspot turns off automatically. To adjust this setting, go to Settings > Network & internet > Mobile Hotspot& tethering > Wi-Fi hotspot > Advanced > Timeout settings

If you’re experiencing performance issues, you can limit the number of connections allowed or temporarily disconnect devices.
  1. Go to Settings > Network & internet > Hotspot & tethering
  2. Touch Wi-Fi hotspot > Advanced > Manage devices
  3. Do any of the following:
    • To limit number of devices allowed, touch Device limit
    • To temporarily disconnect devices until your next hotspot session, under Connected devices, touch the device's name > Disconnect. The device will remain unable to connect until you turn off and restart the hotspot.
To allow only specified devices to connect:
  1. Get the MAC addresses of the devices you want to allow to connect. (Connect devices to the hotspot normally, then go to Manage devices, and touch the name of each connected device to view its MAC address.)
  2. Touch Manage allowed devices > Add allowed device.
  3. For each device, enter the MAC address and device name.
  4. Once you add allowed devices, they are saved unless you delete them, and you can turn this feature on and off by checking or unchecking Allow all devices any time.
To restrict access for a previously allowed device, touch the device name, then touch Delete.
View or change hotspot password
  1. Go to Settings > Network & internet > Hotspot & tethering
  2. Touch Wi-Fi hotspot
  3. Touch Advanced > Hotspot password to see the current password.
  4. To change the password, type over the current password.
Note: Although you can turn off passwords for your hotspot, keeping a password prevents unauthorized usage of your cellular data.
"
keywords: wifi, wireless, connection, connect, wep, wpa

question: " Can I reset the network settings on my motorola one ? "
categories(Name): Master Reset (Restore Factory Settings)|Master Clear (Erase all Data)|-Top FAQs-|Troubleshooting
solution:
"

If you're having problems with Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, cellular data, or hotspot connections you can try resetting all network settings:
  1. Go to Settings > System > Advanced > Reset options
     
  2. Touch Reset Wi-Fi, mobile & Bluetooth > RESET SETTINGS
     
  3. If you're using dual SIMs, select the SIM to reset for mobile data settings.
     
  4. Touch RESET SETTINGS
     
  5. Try to reconnect to Wi-Fi, cellular data, and Bluetooth, or try to share your internet connection again.
"

question:
"

Recording videos on the motorola one

\n"
solution:
"

Record a video

  1. On the viewfinder, touch   to switch to video mode.

  2. If needed, choose the type of video to record:

    • To record a selfie video, touch

  3. If needed, adjust video settings.

  4. To start, touch  

  5. While recording, you can:

    • Take a photo during your video by touching  

    • Pause recording by touching

  6. To stop, touch

  7. To watch your video, touch the thumbnail at bottom right. Then:

    • To view all thumbnails, touch the screen, then touch  to open the Photos app.

    • To view videos or photos later, open the Photos app or other photo app you installed.

 Record a slow-motion video

Take a video, then select a portion to play in slow-motion. You can adjust this any time you play the video.

  1. On the viewfinder, touch   > Slow Motion

  2. To start, touch

  3. To stop, touch  

  4. Touch the thumbnail to open the video.

  5. Use the sliders to surround the frames to play in slow-motion. Or, surround all frames to play the entire video in slow-motion. You can reposition the sliders any time you play the video.

If you don’t want slow motion in the video, move the sliders together to play at normal speed.

 Record a timelapse video

Make time appear to be moving faster. This mode works well for mostly static scenes that change slowly, like a flower opening, or have motion in one area, like traffic. You select the speed before recording the video and can’t adjust it afterwards.

  1. Attach a tripod or set up your phone so that it can’t move while you record.

  2. On the viewfinder, touch   > Timelapse

  3. Select the speed multiplier to use. In general, use a faster speed for longer videos.

  4. To start, touch  

    You’ll see two counters, one that shows the duration of the recording and another that shows the duration the video will play when sped up.

  5. To stop, touch

Adjust video settings

Before recording a video:

  • To turn video stabilization on, touch  

  • To turn the light on, touch  

  • To change video resolution:

    • To change video resolution, touch  Settings and touch Video size for the front or rear camera. Lower resolution videos take up less space, but have lower image quality.

"

question:
"

Take a panoramic photo on the motorola one

\n"
solution:
"
Panoramic photos allow you to pan to capture the whole scene.
 
To take a  panoramic photo:
  1. On the viewfinder, touch  > Panorama
     
  2. Frame one side of the scene.
     
  3. Touch , then slowly pan horizontally or vertically across the scene. Keep your motion smooth and use a steady speed.
     
  4. When you reach the end of your scene, touch
To view panoramas:
  1. In the Photos app, you'll see  on thumbnails of images when you can use immersive view.

    Touch the thumbnail to open the  photo.
     
  2. Do any of the following:
    • To move the photo around with your finger, touch
       
    • To experience the scene as if it were surrounding you, touch  and move your phone around you.
